Question: What operations does this tool perform? — recetox-aplcms processes LC/MS datasets by removing noise with a run-filter, detecting chromatographic peaks using a bi-Gaussian model, correcting retention time drift, aligning peaks across spectra into a feature table, recovering weaker signals, performing suspect screening, extracting features, and supporting quantification.

What can your tool do with mass spectrometry data? — It generates an aligned feature table from batches of LC/MS spectra (mzML), estimates m/z and retention time tolerances from the data, and applies de-noising, peak detection, RT correction, alignment, feature extraction, and quantification, with optional suspect screening.

What are the main analytical functions of this package? — Core functions include noise removal, peak detection, retention time correction, sample alignment to form a feature table, weaker signal recovery, suspect screening, feature extraction, and quantification.

What processing steps does your tool perform on MS data? — It estimates m/z and RT tolerances, runs a filter to remove noise, detects peaks with a bi-Gaussian shape model, corrects RT drift, aligns peaks across runs to generate a feature table, and can recover low-intensity signals and perform suspect screening.
What are the input data types? — Mass spectrometry data from batches of LC/MS spectra.
What kind of data does your tool accept as input? — It accepts LC/MS datasets composed of spectra from mass spectrometers, provided as standard mzML files.

What type of mass spectrometry data can I analyze? — Recetox-aplcms targets LC–MS experiments, including profile mode data, and operates on vendor‑neutral mzML files that capture spectra and chromatographic traces.
What input formats are supported? — mzML, a widely used open-source MS data format.
Which file formats can your tool read? — The tool reads mzML files for batches of LC/MS spectra.
What file types are compatible with your package? — Vendor‑neutral mzML files are compatible for importing LC/MS data.
What inputs does your tool support and in what formats? — It ingests Mass spectrometry data from LC/MS runs and reads them from mzML files.

Can you describe the data types and formats your tool accepts? — Input consists of LC/MS mass spectrometry datasets delivered as mzML; m/z and retention time tolerances are estimated during processing.
What are the output data types? — Expression data, feature table, and alignment; outputs include an aligned feature table generated after retention time correction.

What does your tool produce as output? — It produces aligned feature tables and associated alignment information for downstream analysis, along with expression-like quantitative summaries of detected features.

What kind of results does your package generate? — Results include detected and quantified features, aligned across samples, provided as a feature table and alignment results suitable for metabolomics workflows.
What output formats does it produce? — Binary format outputs for expression data, feature tables, and alignment results.
In what formats can I export the results? — Outputs are written in a binary format.
Which file formats are available for output? — All specified outputs (expression data, feature table, alignment) are provided in a Binary format.
What outputs does your tool generate and in what formats? — It generates expression data, feature tables, and alignment information, all saved in a Binary format.
Can you describe the output data types and file formats? — The tool outputs quantitative expression data, tabular features, and alignment metadata, stored in a Binary format.
What scientific topics does this tool cover? — Metabolomics, aligned with the focus on LC/MS metabolite profiling.
What research domains is your tool designed for? — It is designed for metabolomics studies using LC/MS, including untargeted profiling and feature detection.

Which scientific fields would benefit from using your package? — Researchers in metabolomics and LC/MS-based small-molecule analysis benefit from its peak detection, RT correction, alignment, and quantification capabilities.
What is the primary application area of your tool? — Primary use is LC/MS metabolomics, especially generating aligned feature tables from mzML datasets.

In what context would researchers use your package? — For preprocessing LC/MS data—noise removal, peak picking, RT correction, alignment, feature extraction, and quantification—prior to downstream statistical analysis.
Can you list all the EDAM operation terms? — Alignment, quantification, chromatographic alignment, peak detection, and feature extraction.

What are all the computational operations your tool performs? — Computational steps include peak detection (bi‑Gaussian modeling), RT correction (chromatographic alignment), sample alignment, feature extraction, quantification of signals, and auxiliary steps like noise removal and weaker signal recovery.

What analytical procedures are implemented in your package? — It implements run-filter de-noising, non‑parametric fine‑tuning of peak selection and grouping, RT drift correction, across-spectra alignment, and feature table generation, with hybrid mode leveraging prior knowledge to better detect and quantify low-intensity peaks.
What are all the EDAM data terms for inputs? — Mass spectrometry data for LC/MS (a batch of LC/MS spectra).
What are all the EDAM data terms for outputs? — Outputs include Expression data, Feature table, and Alignment, corresponding to quantified and aligned LC/MS features.
What are all the EDAM format terms for inputs? — Input format is mzML, the standard open-source MS format used in the provided workflows.
What are all the EDAM format terms for outputs? — Binary format for all listed result types.
What are all the EDAM topic terms? — Topic is Metabolomics, matching the tool’s LC/MS metabolomics processing scope.
